node.title: ‘There's a whole community out there just waiting for you’: Ella’s advice to city teens
node.alt: A teenager wearing a white shirt smiles at the camera
node.description: The kindness of a regional town helped Ella breathe fresh air to her city community at a crucial time.
node.content:
["Ella grew up on a quiet street in Melbourne's eastern suburbs.", "With two loving parents and rambunctious younger siblings, the 14-year-old says her life was \"just like any other kid in Melbourne\".", "However, her neighbours were all much older than her, many were renters\u00a0and there weren't many other kids on the street to play with.", "\"We really don't know a lot of people. There's a lot of rental places. Everyone's pretty much in and out around here,\" Ella said.", "Then, her family bought a farm in the Gippsland area, and Ella's eyes were suddenly opened to what a community could feel like.", "
A country welcome
", "The moment Ella's family car pulled up on their new property, neighbours swarmed to welcome the fresh faces.", "\"They came right over to suss us out and introduce themselves, tell us about themselves and the neighbours,\" Ella said.", "Immediately, the family was initiated into the community.", "Ella says she was surprised by how open and welcoming their new neighbours were to the newcomers.", "\"Right away we found out about all the gossip that's been going around,\" she said.", "\"Everyone knows about everyone and their story, and they all look out for each other.", "", "
Ella embraced the openness of the Gippsland community.(ABC News: Karen Brookes)
", "With a sudden abundance of opportunities for friendship with people of all ages, Ella wasted no time building relationships.", "\"We all get along,\" she says. \"Regardless of age, everyone gets along.\"", "As she speaks about the connections she's made, Ella's mum interjects, smiling:\u00a0\"[The kids] have been going out more than they hang out with us.", "\"Especially when [a neighbour] has\u00a0baby sheep, they'll go bottle-feeding the sheep when its lambing time, or they're out cleaning the troughs, or training the next door neighbours'\u00a0dog.\"", "", "
Ella\u2019s mum says her kids spend all their time with the lambs.(Supplied)
", "It\u2019s the shared experiences of the responsibility of livestock that Ella says gives the community the opportunity to provide\u00a0the\u00a0\"acts of kindness\" that make the rural lifestyle so\u00a0rich.\u00a0", "\u201cOur neighbours look out for the cows and, if there\u2019s something wrong, someone will call my Dad.\u00a0We always know if something\u2019s happening,\u201d\u00a0she says.\u00a0", "
'Trying on different hats\u2019\u00a0
", "The benefits of a supportive community in a child\u2019s development are most crucial during early teenage years, says Lisa Mundy from the Murdoch Children\u2019s Research Institute in Melbourne.\u00a0", "\u201cThese early adolescent\u00a0years\u00a0are when\u00a0young people work out where they fit in in the world and work out a space that they\u2019re comfortable in, so friendships become really critically important to that,\u201d Dr Mundy said.\u00a0", "\u201cSo, moving into a community where you feel connected and where you\u2019re able to create those connections with friends and peers, and meeting people who have an interest in what you're doing and have time for you is really important.\u201d\u00a0", "", "
Dr Lisa Mundy says it\u2019s important for parents to encourage teenagers to\u00a0make connections with a range of people.(Supplied)
", "Dr Mundy says building relationships with people of different ages and lifestyles gives children and teenagers a key advantage in developing not only their social skills, but their own sense of identity.", "Not everyone has the opportunity to join a rural community like Ella has, but there are other ways parents can help their children broaden their experiences.", "\"Allowing [teenagers] the space to make their own connections and build their own relationships with friends or other people in the community, as appropriate, but giving them clear boundaries within that, is really important,\" Dr Mundy said.", "\"So, allow your teenager to have those opportunities, to have choice, encourage healthy risks and let them have new and different experiences that can help them build their identity.\"", "", "
Ella says the shared experience of taking care of animals brings the rural community together.(Supplied)
", "It's inevitable that a teenager won't always make the right decision and will often face avoidable consequences.", "Dr Mundy says the best thing a parent can do when things go wrong is to see it as a learning opportunity and support their child through it.", "\"Their brains are still developing, particularly the prefrontal cortex, so they are actually making decisions in a different way to how we as adults do, so they won't always approach the decision-making process in the same way that we will,\" Dr Mundy said.", "\"As long as you have clear boundaries that you've made, together, and they understand why those are in place, have a conversation about what happened and why it went wrong and what decisions they might have made differently in another situation, so they start to build that ability to make sensible, risk-based decisions.\"", "
Building community through COVID-19
", "Ella took that sense of community back to Melbourne and started looking out for people around her at a crucial moment.", "When COVID-19 arrived in Melbourne and the city was plunged into its first lockdown, Ella became concerned about\u00a0the welfare of their 96-year-old neighbour.", "\"A lot of her family who normally go over there every so often \u2026\u00a0couldn't come over as often,\" Ella explained.", "\"We'd help out, give her meals, drop off her paper at her doorstep, take the bins out.", "\"She'd leave a bag of treats out every Sunday to say thank you.\"", "Dr Mundy says there is a great deal of anecdotal evidence to suggest the hardships of lockdowns have helped foster closer relationships between neighbours.", "\"That's what we're hearing, that there is some positive aspect of COVID in terms of spending more time at home and building relationships with your neighbours who you might not have spent time with before,\" she said.", "Taking what she had\u00a0learned from her time in the Gippsland community, Ella has begun using the family dog to build relationships with other Melbourne neighbours, too.", "", "
Ella learned that animals make a great starting point for chit chat with neighbours.(ABC News: Karen Brookes)
", "\"Everyone with a dog will say a quick 'hi' and then continue on with their walk,\" she says.", "\"So, you are able to talk to more people when you have a dog. You can talk about the dog experience and talk about training.\"", "Ella says her time with the people on the farm has changed her perspective on life in the suburbs.", "\"I've realised, there's a whole community out there just waiting for you. You just have to start talking.\"", "The\u00a0ABC\u2019s Takeover Melbourne program gives a voice to young people across Greater Melbourne. If you would like to find more stories\u00a0or learn about the next Takeover Melbourne intake\u00a0go to\u00a0the Takeover website."]
